metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Howrah Municipality & Ors.

facts.text: About 41 bighas of land in Salkia, Howrah acquired by Government of West Bengal for market place and placed at disposal of Howrah Municipality (first respondent) on condition to use for public market, not for other purpose without permission, and to be resumed if public market not established within reasonable time.
Second respondent took lease of about 21 bighas 9 kotas from first respondent; respondents 3 and 4 took sub-lease from second respondent.
Title Suit No. 15 of 1959 filed by second respondent decreed on January 25, 1960; suit No. 10 of 1959 by Municipality dismissed.
Title Suit No. 34 of 1961 for possession of 41 bighas decreed in favour of State (appellant) on July 21, 1961; appeal by Municipality pending as First Appeal No. 135 of 1963.

Additional District Judge, Howrah decided three Land Acquisition Reference Cases (Nos. 21, 40 of 1958 and 13 of 1959) on June 27, 1963, awarding compensation of about Rs. 16,00,000 to respondents; decrees signed on September 21, 1963.
Second respondent levied execution on award; State filed objections under s. 47 CPC on August 27, 1964 claiming award not executable due to decree in TS No. 34/1961.
Objections to execution rejected; matter referred to Legal Remembrancer, West Bengal.
On March 4, 1965, discovered that no appeals filed against Land Acquisition References judgment.
On April 15, 1965, State lawyer advised filing under Art. 227 Constitution.
Writ petitions under Art. 227 filed on May 17, 1965; High Court declined rule but granted stay of execution for one month, directed appeals with s.5 applications within one month.
On June 17, 1965, High Court extended time and stay by two weeks.
On July 1, 1965, High Court directed obtaining stay from appeals bench.

Three appeals against Land Acquisition References filed on July 3, 1965; returned on July 5, 1965 for delay of one year seven months twenty two days; re-presented on July 7, 1965 with s.5 applications.
High Court issued notice on July 7, 1965; additional affidavit filed January 18, 1966 with Legal Remembrancer Manual references and letters.
High Court order on January 21, 1966: not satisfied with sufficient cause, discharged rules, liberty to reconsider on better materials, no costs.
Reply from ex-Government Pleader dated January 29, 1966 received; applications for reconsideration filed.
High Court notice on June 3, 1966; common order August 18, 1966 dismissing s.5 applications for unexplained delay from August 27, 1964 to July 3, 1965; stay continued for fortnight.
Writ petitions under Art. 227 withdrawn as infructuous on September 28, 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant (State) has shown sufficient cause under s.5 of Limitation Act, 1963 to condone delay of over one year nine months in filing appeals against Land Acquisition References decrees signed September 21, 1963.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay from September 21, 1963 to August 27, 1964 explained; objections u/s 47 CPC filed on August 27, 1964; unaware of no appeal until March 4, 1965 due to departmental issues; advised Art.227 on April 15, 1965, filed May 17, 1965; appeals filed July 3, 1965 per court directions; no negligence, acted diligently post-discovery; substantial justice requires condonation as respondents trespassers per TS 34/1961 decree.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5 Limitation Act, 1963; Art. 227 Constitution; s.47 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court failed to consider affidavits, disbelieve facts, or find negligence; judicial discretion under s.5 to advance substantial justice.

respondent_arguments.text: Delay from September 21, 1963 unexplained; even from August 27, 1964 to July 3, 1965 unexplained; same Government Pleader in TS 34/1961 and LA cases, aware of need to appeal; departmental separation no excuse; State not entitled to liberal construction.
TS 34/1961 decree not binding on second respondent (struck off defendants) or sub-lessees; Municipality not trespasser.

court_reasoning.text: High Court order brief, no reasons, no disbelief of affidavits, no finding of negligence; accepts explanation upto August 27, 1964; period August 27, 1964 to March 4, 1965 explained by discovery of no appeal; post March 4, 1965 diligent steps taken including lawyer advice (even if wrong), writs filed, appeals per court directions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No negligence or inaction imputable; acted on lawyer advice; sufficient cause shown.

court_reasoning.text: s.5 discretion to advance substantial justice; liberal construction if no negligence; same rules for State and private parties but considerations apply equally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court duty to scrutinize reasons on merits.

holdings.text: Sufficient cause shown under s.5 Limitation Act; delay condoned; appeals against LA References to be taken on file and disposed according to law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramlal, Motilal and Chhotelal v. Rewa Coalfields Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: s.5 interpretation: balance vested right vs substantial justice; liberal if no negligence.
s.5 liberal construction for substantial justice absent negligence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shakuntala Devi Jain v. Kuntal Kumari
precedents_cited.relevance: No want of bona fides or negligence deprives s.5 protection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Narain Joshi v. Parmeshwar Narain Mahta
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court considered reasons fully; here no such consideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kunwar Rajendra Singh v. Rai Rajeshwar Bali
precedents_cited.relevance: Wrong legal advice may constitute sufficient cause.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Condonation of delay in filing appeals if sufficient cause shown.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writs to quash lower court judgment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside High Court order dated August 18, 1966 dismissing s.5 applications; allowed applications under s.5 Limitation Act; condoned delay; directed High Court to take appeals on file and dispose according to law; early disposal suggested; liberty on compensation.
outcome.costs: Appellant to pay taxed costs of first respondent and respondents 2-4 in Supreme Court and High Court proceedings under s.5.

key_quotes.text: "the words sufficient cause should receive a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence nor inaction nor want of bona fides is imputable to a party."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the High Court had considered the reasons given by the appellant, and rejected them as false or if the High Court had held that there has been such total inaction or negligence on the part of the appellant as would deprive the State of the protection under s. 5 of the Limitation Act, the position would be different."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of High Court's failure to analyze.

key_quotes.text: "we are satisfied that in the circumstances of this case, the appellant has shown sufficient cause and it is not possible to impute to the appellant want of bona fides or such inaction or negligence as would deprive them of the protection of S. 5 of the Limitation Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
